reviewText: I loved this when I was a kid and I'm glad to say I still do now at 42! This is one of Jerry Lewis's finest with some really clever visual gags and an inspired use of sound(look out for the apple scene.)Kathleen Freeman is also great as the long suffering head nurse.The whole cast is excellent really and Everett Sloane is on fine form as the very un-pc director of the hospital.A great film and very nearly up there with Lewis's(not Eddie Murphy's!) The Nutty Professor.

reviewText: This is a hilarious nuthouse romp (although Jerry makes everywhere a nuthouse)!The common Lewis flaw of getting carried away with a pathos-driven subplot (this time Susan Oliver trying to bump herself off) bogs things down a bit, but the sight gag totals serve to mellow it out in general.The only real mistake happens at the tail end of the flick, when a wild chase ensues, ending with Jerry's boss rolling on a stretcher down the street, along a pier and into the ocean.But right before that happens, two ambulances collide on either side of Jerry - one with Jerry's girlfriend in it and the other... shows no driver!In fact, right before the crash, the movie's director Frank Tashlin even goes to all the trouble of showing us in a closeup that the ambulance's cab is empty, except that someone is still somehow turning the steering wheel.What's up with THAT?!

reviewText: I was born with a severe heart condition.  In 1979, at age five, I had a brain abcess.  In 1982 I had opened heart surgery.  In 2004 I had a pacemaker implanter.  This movie's medical humor is funny--and as you have read; I ought to know!This is also one of the best romantic comedies I have seen (Jerry Lewis or otherwise).  Believe it or not, it's a tearjerker.

reviewText: Come on, now.....  this has to be, by far, the best Jerry Lewis movie made.  It's full of 1960's comedy gags and ridiculous situations, as well as the appearances of a couple of actresses in Jerry's previous movies.  I had forgotten about actress Susan Oliver portraying Jerry's former high school heart throb.  I was also surprised about the appearance of 60's comedian Jack E. Leonard, making a cameo appearance as a mentally unstable person (which, by many observations, would be considered "type-casting"...... heh).Jerry Lewis is the poor schmo here, as he so often plays, delivering his best slapstick, crossed eyes and exaggerated faces of someone who just flat out "tries too hard" in nearly everything he does or touches.  The plot is the thing here.  This is so very entertaining, that it had family members laughing until wiping their eyes or urinating their undies after a Thanksgiving dinner one year.  Yeah.......  REALLY.Thanks, Jerry, for your fun movies.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Jerry Lewis is Jerome Littlefield, an orderly at a mental institution who acts crazier than the patients.  Since Frank Tashlin directed this movie, Jerry is free to concentrate solely on his performance, which he does to perfection.  Once again Jerry is the lovable loser, who was thrown out of medical school because he felt the symptoms of every patient he diagnosed.  This movie features a lot of great sight gags.  Jerry fixes a television set in a patient's room that has poor reception, also known as snow.  When he takes out the front of the TV, snow comes flying out of the set and soon fills the room!  A patient is in a full body cast from head to toe, looking like a plastered mummy.  Jerry accidentally knocks him over, the patient goes rolling down a hill and crashes into a tree.  There's pieces of broken plaster everywhere, but no body!  Jerry declares, "I lost a patient!"  The movie concludes with one of the craziest chase scenes in movie history, as a wheeled stretcher with an injured man on it rolls out of the back of an ambulance and continues to roll down hills, while first one, then two ambulances chase him.  This movie features more LPMs (laughs per minute) than most modern comedies, and is one of Jerry's funniest films.
Title: N/A

reviewText: If laughter is the best medicine, this film is the pharmacy.Jerry Lewis is Jerome Littlefield, the disorderly orderly. Jerome is an orderly in a private hospital that seems to be halfmedical hospital and half mental hospital. And with Jerome acting as their orderly, more and more people are slipping over tothe nut house wing.Jerome is one of the basic Lewis characters. The really nice well intended kid that is just too inept to do anything right. Awalking disaster looking for a place to happen. (Think Stan Laurel) He proceeds to drive both staff and patients crazy.The film is filled with funny medical gags. For example one morning before giving an elderly patient his breakfast he proceedsto forceably brush the old mans teeth for him. Until in the middle of this process he notices that the old fellows teeth are sittingin a glass of water next to his bed.The supporting characters also add much to the film. Especially Kathleen Freeman as nurse Higgins.I loved this movie when I was a kid. Now I find at age 52 it`s still just as funny. Timeless humor.
summary: Laughter is the best medicine and this is the pharmacy

reviewText: When the sight gags pay off, we have a Classic; and predictably, we have too many of them which go on too long, with absolutely *no* payoff. But the movie's real strength is actually in the hard story, about Jerry's High School sweetheart (his imagined sweetheart?), now a very reluctant patient (driven to an overdose by a bad relationship) of a decidedly confused Med. student, alternating between professional and attendant. His problem in the Health field is that not only does he over-empathize with the patient, he actually has "sympathy pains". (The funniest parts occur in the opening scenes, along these lines, one devastastingly funny, as Alice Pearce describes her kidney condition and a water fountain is enough to send Jerry into delirium, as he bolts for.... Wierdly, this comedy mechanism is suddenly dropped; it reappears at a crucial point....not to give too much away of the plot). He sustains by the sentimentality of The Sanitarium Head Adminsitrator. She was in love with Jerry's dad.Another strength is in the relatability to today! Everett Sloane, a Lewis player, plays the head of the Board, and has no tolerance for anything other than cash on the barrelhead, later for sensitivities. As spacey as Jerry is, he is aware of the bottom line, and goes the extra mile to care for and actually *pay* for Diane Mcbain, his teenage love.Although, it can get exasperating, as 1930s (surreal) slapstick does not mix with light drama, and we feel sorry for Susan Oliver, a staff Nurse, who gets more and more confused on her own, with her feelings for Jerry, and for Jerome's Supervisor, the great Lewis player Kathleen Freeman, who gets one step closer each day to signing herself in, as her staffer finds multiiple ways to drive her up the wall, almost literally; the fan/viewer needs to hang in there for a very satisfying, overall, effort.This should be a strong four star movie for Jerry but Lewis did not direct and write and Tashlin doesn't seem to know hwo to blend the outlandish stuff with the often moving adult scenario, as stated above. Still recommended for the good script and Lewis' performance."What could have been".(Beautifully filmed, well scored).
Title: N/A

reviewText: Another hysterical Lewis vehicle has him playing hospital orderly Jerome Littlefield, who's his own worst enemy as well as a bumbling menace to both staff & patients. Directed with comic brilliance by Lewis' mentor Frank Tashlin, it's filled with great zany Lewis moments such as:Lewis struggling with laundry, then disappearing down a chute.His hysterical reactions of "sympathy pains" as a loud-mouthed patient graphically describes her ailments.A wild, cartoonish sight gag has a straight-jacketed Lewis crawling across the screen...then passed up by a speedy cartoon snail!A running gag with a patient mummified in a cast (who, at one point, rolls wildly down a hill).Lewis turning a patient's room into a blizzard of feathers.A wild, gag-filled ambulance finale.The film also has the terrific Kathleen Freeman, once again serving as Lewis' comic foil & wonderfully boiling over to his antics. And I cackled with triumph when the mean, stodgy administrator became a victim of his own policies. I gave the film four stars because of both Lewis & Tashlin's maudlin melodramatic soap opera of a suicidal girl's subplot, which is painfully dated for today's audiences. But as a comedy, it has some wonderfully zany moments.

reviewText: The Disorderly Orderly (1964) was the sixth and last Jerry Lewis comedy to be directed by Frank Tashlin (Rock-A-Bye Baby,The Geisha Boy,Cinderfella,It's Only Money,Who's Minding the Store?), who also wrote the screenplay.  The movie has a soap opera type story with various psychological undertones, mixed with Lewis' trademark comedic bits.  Although the it finishes with an impressive action sequence, for much of the film Lewis' comic antics are actually dialed down a bit, as he is playing a character that is more in line with his actual age (38).  With the title song sung by Sammy Davis Jr., the film features a solid cast, that includes Lewis' regulars, Kathleen Freeman and Del Moore.Because he has empathetic reactions to the ailments of others, Jerome Littlefield (Lewis) was kicked out of medical school, and now works as an orderly at the Whitestone Sanitarium and Hospital, which is run by Dr. Jean Howard (Glenda Farrell) with the help of head nurse Maggie Higgins (Freeman).  Jerome is in love with Julie Blair (Karen Sharpe), a nurse at the facility.  His ailment creates problems for him on the job.  When a patient named Mrs. Fuzzyby (Alice Pearce) describes her various health problems, Jerome reacts as if he is suffering from the same ailments, from dripping bile, to a compound fracture, to weak kidneys.Unrealized love is a major theme, as Dr. Howard had romantic feelings for Jerome's father who was a doctor, that never flowered.  Jerome had his head messed up, by a girl he secretly loved in high school.  When this same girl, now a woman, arrives at the sanitarium after attempting to commit suicide, Jerome has to deal with those feelings again.  The patient, Susan Andrews (Susan Oliver), feels unloved, and is angry at men.  Although she does not remember Jerome, he secretly arranges to pay for her hospital expenses, when hospital administrator Mr. Tuffington (Everett Sloane) forbids taking charity cases.Aware of Littlefield's secret love for Susan, Julie is concerned, but working overtime to pay for Susan's care, Jerome has little time for her.  Lewis' comic filler interludes are hit and miss, although his empathetic scenes with patient Mrs. Fuzzyby (Alice Pearce) are golden ("drip, drip, drip").  Pearce would later assume the role of Gladys Kravitz on TV's Bewitched, but sadly would pass away from cancer in 1966, at only 48.  She was posthumously awarded an Emmy, for her performance as Samantha Stevens' nosy neighbor.The beautiful and fiery-eyed Susan Oliver (Star Trek pilot: The Cage) was a very good actress, and she adds a real spark here.  Susan catches Jerome spying on her in her room and treats him with disgust, and is confrontational with everyone, until her psychiatrist Dr. Davenport (Del Moore) informs her who's been paying her bills.  In an extended kissing scene between Susan and Jerome, he is finally cured of his psychological disorder.The final action sequence, a wild chase featuring two ambulances and Mr. Tuffington strapped to a gurney, was outrageous back in 1964, and featuring mostly real stunts, it is still rather impressive even now.  Sure, the stacks and stacks of Hi-C cans being knocked over is overkill, but it's just solid product placement, and excess is characteristic of Lewis' style.The Disorderly Orderly has a decent story, that isn't seriously derailed by Lewis' trademark gags.  Jerry is still Jerry, but under the guidance of a director not named Jerry Lewis, he's a bit more restrained.  Playing a character with slightly more maturity is also a positive, along with a solid supporting cast.  The extras, some vintage outtakes and a trailer, are interesting, but a little skimpy, as there is no commentary by Lewis.  Among the Lewis/Tashlin collaborations, along with TheThe Geisha Boy(1958) andWho's Minding the Store(1963), if you're a Jerry fan, this is one should you have in your collection.  Rating: 3.5 stars.
summary: one of the better Tashlin/Lewis collaborations, has a fantastic finish...

reviewText: I remembered seeing Cinderfella a long time ago and thinking it was so funny, so when I came across this film, I was excited about seeing it.  Well, let's just say I could not finish this one.  It just wasn't funny.  Jerry Lewis was just loud and silly but that doesn't automatically equal funny in my book.  I am going to rent Cinderfella soon and see if I still think that is funny.  If I don't find it funny, I will amend this review because then I know my sense of humor has changed and I guess this really wouldn't be a fair review. Until then, I can't give it more than a few stars. It wasn't absolutely awful, but just wasn't fun or funny enough to hold my interest.
summary: Maybe my sense of humor has changed or something????
